issue.title: SetDamping / GetDamping is totally wrong in AtlasPlugin.cpp

content.raw:
Thanks for the report. I'll address these in order:

1. [AtlasPlugin.cpp:1147](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/ef20eebcb1d8b14e650fca70724c9f14d087327d/drcsim_gazebo_ros_plugins/src/AtlasPlugin.cpp?at=default#cl-1147): this looks like a botched merge in 8c87603 that slipped through code review. We will fix it.

1. [AtlasPlugin.cpp:1298](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/ef20eebcb1d8b14e650fca70724c9f14d087327d/drcsim_gazebo_ros_plugins/src/AtlasPlugin.cpp?at=default#cl-1298): I'll check with @hsu about what is supposed to happen here.

1. [AtlasPlugin.cpp:2673](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/ef20eebcb1d8b14e650fca70724c9f14d087327d/drcsim_gazebo_ros_plugins/src/AtlasPlugin.cpp?at=default#cl-2673): I believe this is correct. The velocity feedback term consists of `jointDampingCoef` * (`targetVelocity` - `actualVelocity`). The `actualVelocity` term is indeed handled by the physics engine, so we are just adding the `targetVelocity` (ie. `this->atlasCommand.velocity[i]`) term here.
content.html:
Thanks for the report. I'll address these in order:

  1. AtlasPlugin.cpp:1147: this looks like a botched merge in 8c87603 that slipped through code review. We will fix it.

  2. AtlasPlugin.cpp:1298: I'll check with @hsu about what is supposed to happen here.

  3. AtlasPlugin.cpp:2673: I believe this is correct. The velocity feedback term consists of jointDampingCoef * (targetVelocity - actualVelocity). The actualVelocity term is indeed handled by the physics engine, so we are just adding the targetVelocity (ie. this->atlasCommand.velocity[i]) term here.

issue.title: SetDamping / GetDamping is totally wrong in AtlasPlugin.cpp

content.raw:
according to the [ROS API table](#!/osrf/drcsim/wiki/DRC/UserGuide) the function [bool AtlasPlugin::GetJointDamping(...) Atlas.cpp:1298](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/ef20eebcb1d8b14e650fca70724c9f14d087327d/drcsim_gazebo_ros_plugins/src/AtlasPlugin.cpp?at=default#cl-1298) is supposed to return the joint's viscous damping coefficient.

Looks like the table could use some content and cosmetic updates.
content.html:
according to the ROS API table the function bool AtlasPlugin::GetJointDamping(...) Atlas.cpp:1298 is supposed to return the joint's viscous damping coefficient.

Looks like the table could use some content and cosmetic updates.

issue.title: SetDamping / GetDamping is totally wrong in AtlasPlugin.cpp

content.raw: So, @hsu, are you saying that `GetJointDamping` is working correctly?
content.html: So, @hsu, are you saying that GetJointDamping is working correctly?

issue.title: SetDamping / GetDamping is totally wrong in AtlasPlugin.cpp

content.raw: Yes, `GetJointDamping` is supposed to return the amount of viscous damping in the physical model (not the controller). So I believe it's doing the right thing.  @siyuanfeng, are you looking for the overall damping the joint sees from a combination of joint controller and the physical model?
content.html: Yes, GetJointDamping is supposed to return the amount of viscous damping in the physical model (not the controller). So I believe it's doing the right thing. @siyuanfeng, are you looking for the overall damping the joint sees from a combination of joint controller and the physical model?

issue.title: SetDamping / GetDamping is totally wrong in AtlasPlugin.cpp
SetDamping / GetDamping is totally wrong in AtlasPlugin.cpp

content.raw: @siyuanfeng the combined "damping coefficient" is a fictitious value that is not quite physical. We are using implicit damping to cheat and achieve stability for larger controller d-terms.  You can lower the max joint damping value to match the actual joint damping value of the joint, and the controller d-terms will be applied explicitly, which is a more physically realistic scenario.
content.html: @siyuanfeng the combined "damping coefficient" is a fictitious value that is not quite physical. We are using implicit damping to cheat and achieve stability for larger controller d-terms. You can lower the max joint damping value to match the actual joint damping value of the joint, and the controller d-terms will be applied explicitly, which is a more physically realistic scenario.

issue.title: SetDamping / GetDamping is totally wrong in AtlasPlugin.cpp

content.raw:
ok, here is what I wanted, and let's figure out how to get there.

In my model, I am assuming a perfect second order model, and I am doing
pure torque control. So I need to somehow compensate out the additive
"damping" you added in the physics on in my feedforward torques. Right now,
I am assuming a simple viscous damping model, which I believe is what you
guys are trying to get in the infinite computational budget case. And for
this simple model, I need to know the effective damping coefficient. I am
open to more complex damping model, but at the end of the day, I need some
model with some numbers from you guys that accurately reflect what's going
on in the simulator.

I also think it's desirable for me to turn off damping completely, which is
not an option in the current setup, since it always get min to the default.
I might be wrong on this.
I did try hack AtlasPlugin so that there is not damping, by getting rid of
the additive force, and SetDamping(0,0), the simulator didn't blow up. And
I got what I wanted as well in that case.

thanks
content.html:
ok, here is what I wanted, and let's figure out how to get there.

In my model, I am assuming a perfect second order model, and I am doing pure torque control. So I need to somehow compensate out the additive "damping" you added in the physics on in my feedforward torques. Right now, I am assuming a simple viscous damping model, which I believe is what you guys are trying to get in the infinite computational budget case. And for this simple model, I need to know the effective damping coefficient. I am open to more complex damping model, but at the end of the day, I need some model with some numbers from you guys that accurately reflect what's going on in the simulator.

I also think it's desirable for me to turn off damping completely, which is not an option in the current setup, since it always get min to the default. I might be wrong on this. I did try hack AtlasPlugin so that there is not damping, by getting rid of the additive force, and SetDamping(0,0), the simulator didn't blow up. And I got what I wanted as well in that case.

thanks

issue.title: SetDamping / GetDamping is totally wrong in AtlasPlugin.cpp

content.raw:
@siyuanfeng 

To get zero viscous joint damping from the physics solution, I believe you can achieve that by:

  - setting [high bandwidth joint velocity implicit damping `kp_velocity`](#!/osrf/drcsim/wiki/DRC/UserGuide#markdown-header-high-bandwidth-joint-velocity-implicit-damping-via-kp_velocity) terms to zero. Use [`kd_position` (explicit position derivative error control)](markdown-header-atlas-per-joint-servo-controllers) instead.
  - Call [ROS service](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/default/atlas_msgs/srv/SetJointDamping.srv?at=default) [SetJointDamping](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/ef20eebcb1d8b14e650fca70724c9f14d087327d/drcsim_gazebo_ros_plugins/src/AtlasPlugin.cpp?at=default#cl-1255) and set model damping coefficients to zero.

This should remove any physics based viscous joint damping for the simulated model. Let us know if this does what you need. If not, we can instrument something different?
content.html:
@siyuanfeng

To get zero viscous joint damping from the physics solution, I believe you can achieve that by:

  • setting high bandwidth joint velocity implicit damping kp_velocity terms to zero. Use kd_position (explicit position derivative error control) instead.
  • Call ROS service SetJointDamping and set model damping coefficients to zero.

This should remove any physics based viscous joint damping for the simulated model. Let us know if this does what you need. If not, we can instrument something different?

issue.title: SetDamping / GetDamping is totally wrong in AtlasPlugin.cpp

content.raw: Sounds good to me, as long as I can set it to zero, I am happy. thanks
content.html: Sounds good to me, as long as I can set it to zero, I am happy. thanks
